abstract.text: We present results from a search for solar axions with the COSINE-100 detector. We find no evidence of solar axion events from a data set of 6,303.9 kg•days exposure and set a 90 % confidence level upper limit on the axion-electron coupling, g ae , at 1.70 × 10 −11 for an axion mass less than 1 keV/c 2 . This limit excludes QCD axions heavier than 0.59 eV/c 2 in the DFSZ model and 168.1 eV/c 2 in the KSVZ model.

Introduction

An axion, a pseudo-Nambu-Goldstone boson introduced by Wilczek  [1] and Weinberg [2], arises in the Peccei-Quinn solution of the strong CP problem [3]. Even though the original axion model [1,2] was ruled out by laboratory experiments, KSVZ (Kim-Shifman-Vainstein-Zakharov) [4,5] and DFSZ (Dine-Fischler-Srednicki-Zhitnitskii) [6,7] invisible axion models are not excluded by terrestrial experiments or astrophysics considerations [8].
One of the most sensitive techniques for detecting axions suggested in Ref. [9] was searching astrophysical

Email address: hyunsulee@ibs.re.kr (H.S. Lee) 1 Present address: Department of Physics, Carleton University, Ottawa, Ontario, K1S 5B6, Canada objects such as a Sun that would constitute an intense source of the axions (solar axions). The solar axions are expected to be produced in the Sun via following process [10],
• Compton scattering: γ + e → e + a
• Axio-recombination: e + A → A − + a
• Axio-deexcitation:
• Axio-bremsstrahlung: e + A → e + A + a

• Electron-electron collision: e + e → e + e + a where e is an electron, a is an axion and A is an atom. The total axion flux on the surface of the Earth produced from the Sun was estimated in Ref. [10] and is shown in Fig. 1 (a).

In this paper, we present results from a solar axion search performed with the COSINE-100 experiment [11,12,13]. A data set corresponding to 59.5 days exposure with 106 kg of low background NaI(Tl) crystals was analyzed. We consider the axions that are produced in the Sun and propagate to the Earth. We restrict the search to axion mass m a < 1 keV/c 2 which matches the validity range of the flux calculations [10].

Axions may give signals in detectors through their coupling to photons (g aγ ), electrons (g ae ), and nuclei (g aN ). The coupling g ae can be observed via scattering off the electron of the NaI(Tl) crystals through the axioelectric effect [14,15,16,17,18], a + A → e + A + where A is either a Na or I atom. The cross section for axio-electric interactions [17,18] is,

where E a is the axion energy, σ pe is the photoelectric cross section for either Na or I [19], g ae is the axionelectron coupling, β a is the axion velocity over the speed of light, α is the fine structure constant, and m e is the electron mass. The cross section in case of g ae = 1 for both Na and I atoms is shown in Fig. 1 (b).
COSINE-100 setup and data

COSINE-100 is a dedicated experiment to test an observation of annual modulation in the event rate observed by DAMA/LIBRA experiment [20,21] utilizing a 4 × 2 array of NaI(Tl) crystals with a total weight of 106 kg located at the Yangyang underground laboratory. The crystals are immersed in 2,200 L of linear alkyl benzene (LAB)-based liquid scintillator (LS), which acts as a veto for multiple hit events [22]. Shielding structures of copper, lead, and plastic scintillator surround the liquid scintillator to reduce the background contribution from external radiation and to veto cosmic-rays [11,23] as shown in Fig. 2. Data from the two-month period between 20 October 2016 and 19 December 2016 are used in this analysis. This period was very stable with no environmental abnormality.

Each of the eight NaI(Tl) crystals is coupled with two high quantum efficiency photomultiplier tubes (PMTs), R12669SEL selected for high quantum efficiency, Hamamatsu photonics. An event is triggered when coincident single photoelectrons in both PMTs from a single crystal are observed within a 200 ns time window. If an event is triggered, waveforms from all eight crystals are recorded during 8 µs windows around the hit. The eight crystals are named crystal-1 to crystal-8. Six crystals have light yields of approximately 15 photoelectrons/keV so that 2 keV analysis thresholds can be applied. However, two crystals, crystal-5 and crystal-8, have lower light yields and present 4 keV and 8 keV analysis thresholds, respectively [11,12]. The energy calibration was done with 3 keV X-rays from 40 K and 46.5 keV γ-rays from 210 Pb, which are internal background radiations in the crystal.

Because of low cross-section for solar axion interactions, a solar axion interacts at most only once while traversing the COSINE-100 detector. Therefore, the solar axion search dataset requires: a signal in one crystal and no signal in any other crystals, the liquid scintillator or the muon detector. Events with hits in other crystals or the liquid scintillator are selected as multiple-hit events and used for the development of event selection criteria, energy calibration, efficiency determination and background assessment as described in Refs. [12,24,25]. Multivariate machine learning algorithms, Boosted Decision Trees (BDTs) [26], are trained to discriminate PMT-induced noise events from radiation induced scintillation events. Multiple-hit events produced by Compton scattering of γ-rays from a 60 Co calibration source, weighted to match the energy spectrum of the expected background, were used as a scintillation signal sample. Single-hit data were used as a training sample containing both the scintillation signals and PMT noise. A description of the variables used for the training is given in Ref. [27].

The efficiencies of the selection criteria are determined with the multiple-hit events from the 60 Co source data and are consistent with those measured using the multiple-hit events in the data sample that contains 3 keV 40 K peaks as described in Ref. [12]. On average, a 70 % selection efficiency at 2 keV is obtained for the low-threshold six crystals.

The predominant backgrounds in the solar axion search region of interest (ROI) are γ and β radiation produced by radioactive contaminants internal to the crystals or on their surfaces, from external detector components, and cosmogenic activation. These backgrounds are modeled using the Geant4 [28] based detector simulation described in Ref. [24]. Several sources of uncertainties in the background model are included in this analysis. The largest uncertainties are those associated with the efficiency, which include statistical errors in the efficiency determination with the 60 Co calibration and systematic errors derived from the independent crosschecks. Uncertainties in the energy resolution and nonlinear responses of the NaI(Tl) crystals [29] as well as 210 Pb modeling [24] are accounted. Figure 3 shows the comparison of the measured energy spectrum and the estimated one using the simulated events with their as-  We generate solar axion interactions in the COSINE-100 detector setup using the solar axion flux and cross sections discussed in Section 1. The generated events produce the signals through the COSINE-100 detector simulation, and the simulated events are analyzed using the same selection criteria that are applied to the data. In Fig. 3, the simulated solar axion energy spectra for m a = 0 keV/c 2 and m a = 1 keV/c 2 for g ae = 1× 10 −10 are overlaid on the measured background spectrum of crystal-7. No distinct differences for the two ax-  ion masses are seen. We, therefore, use only two axion masses to describe axion signals between m a =0 keV/c 2 and m a =1 keV/c 2 .
To estimate the signals induced by solar axion, we do a binned maximum likelihood fit to the measured energy spectrum, which is given by

where, N ch is the number of crystals, N bin is the number energy bins, N bkg is the number of background components, N syst is the number of systematic nuisance parameters, n i j is the number of observed counts and µ i j is the total model expectation by summing all N bkg background components and a solar axion signal component after application of a shape change due to N syst systematic effects. In the first product of Gaussians, x k is the amount of the k th background component, α k is the mean of x k and σ x k is its uncertainty. In the second product of Gaussians y l is the l th systematic parameter and σ y l is its uncertainty. All crystals are fit simultaneously. The Bayesian Analysis Tookit [30] is used with probability density functions that are based on shapes of the simulated solar axion signals and the evaluated backgrounds. As seen in the formula, a linear prior for the signal is applied. The means and uncertainties of the Gaussian priors for the various components of the backgrounds are determined from the model fitted to the data [24]. To avoid biassing the axion search, the fitter has been tested with pseudo experiments. For each axion mass, we performed 1,000 simulated experiments with the expected backgrounds and no axion signals included. From this procedure, we calculate the expected 90% confidence level (CL) limits.  Figure 4: (color online) The summed energy spectrum of the six crystals (black points) is shown with the best fit for m a = 0 keV/c 2 (blue solid line) overlaid with ±1σ (green) and ±2σ (yellow) shaded region of the systematic uncertainties in the background model. For the comparison with the possible signal shape, we inserted a solar axion signal assuming g ae =4 × 10 −11 (red dotted line). The lower panel shows the residuals between the data and the best fit, normalized to the best fit.

Data fits are performed for two selected solar axion masses: m a = 0 keV/c 2 and m a = 1 keV/c 2 . An example of a maximum likelihood fit with m a = 0 keV/c 2 is shown in Fig. 4. For both masses (0.0 keV/c 2 and 1.0 keV/c 2 ), the data fits found no excess of events that could be given by solar axion signals in our data. The posterior signal probabilities were consistent with zero in both fits. We determine 90% CL limits of the axion-electron coupling, g ae < 1.70 × 10 −11 for m a = 0 keV to 1 keV and exclude QCD axions heavier than 0.59 eV/c 2 in the DFSZ model and 168.1 eV/c 2 in the KSVZ model. Figure 5 shows the observed 90% CL limit with the ±1σ and ±2σ bands from pseudo-experiments.  Figure 5: The observed 90% CL exclusion limits (red line) on the axion-electron coupling (g ae ) for the first 59.5 days data of COSINE-100 are shown together with the 68% and 95% probability bands for the expected 90% CL limit assuming the backgroundonly hypothesis. The limits are compared with the results set by XMASS [31], EDELWEISS-III [32], KIMS [33], XENON100 [34], PandaX-II [35], and LUX [36] experiments together with indirect astrophysical bounds of solar neutrino [37].
Summary

A search for solar axions with a 59.5 day exposure of 106 kg NaI(Tl) in the COSINE-100 dark matter search experiment has been performed. Here we apply the recent prediction for the solar axion flux that assumes that axions produce electron recoil signals in the NaI(Tl) detector through the axio-electric effects. There is no excess of events that could be attributed to solar axion interactions and we determined a 90% CL limit of the axion-electron coupling, g ae < 1.70 × 10 −11 for m a = 0 keV to 1 keV. This excludes QCD axions heavier than 0.59 eV/c 2 in the DFSZ model and 168.1 eV/c 2 in the KSVZ model.

Figure 1: (color online) (a) The flux of solar axions on the Earth considering the Compton scattering, axio-recombination, axio-deexcitation, axio-bremsstrahlung and electron-electron collision mechanisms[10] with an axion-electron coupling of g ae = 10 −13 is shown. (b) Axio-electric cross sections for Na (dotted red line ) and I (solid black line) atoms are presented for m a = 0.0 keV/c 2 with g ae = 1.

Figure 3: Energy spectrum of the data with applied efficiency (points) is compared with the predicted background spectrum for crystal-7, with 1 σ and 2 σ systematic uncertainty bands. The simulated axion energy spectra for m a = 0 keV/c 2 (dotted red line) and m a = 1 keV/c 2 (solid blue line) for g ae = 1×10 −10 are overlaid for comparison.
